translated: The Parivāra🔽The Headings of the Origins in Brief
The Summary of the Origins
All formations are impermanent,
and what is subject to suffering is insubstantial;
Nibbāna is the only true reality,
and all conditioned things are insubstantial.
Before the Buddha, the Light of the World,
had arisen, the Buddha’s Dispensation had disappeared.
The names of the shared qualities
were not handed down.
Having done various difficult things
and fulfilled the perfections,
the Great Heroes arose,
becoming the eyes of the world with its gods.
They taught the true Dhamma,
which leads to the destruction of suffering and to happiness.
Aṅgīrasa, the Sakyan Sage,
had compassion for all beings.
The Lion, the most excellent of all beings,
taught the three Piṭakas:
the Sutta, the Abhidhamma,
and the Vinaya of great value.
Thus the true Dhamma was handed down
as long as the Vinaya remained.
The two Vibhaṅgas,

original: khandhakā yā ca mātikā.🔽Mālā suttaguṇeneva,🔽parivārena ganthitā;
analyzed: khandhakā yā ca mātikā  mālā sutta guṇena iva  parivārena ganthitā
translated: the Khandhakas, and the Mātikā,🔽were strung together like a garland🔽with the thread of the Sutta Parivāra.
The origins of the Parivāra
were fixed by the one who composed it.
The other origins are mixed up,
they are seen in the Sutta above.
Therefore train in the surrounding text,
one who loves the Dhamma is very clever.”
The thirteen origins
In the Vibhaṅga two are laid down,
they recite on the Uposatha day;
I will explain the origins,
listen to me as I tell you.
The first offense entailing expulsion,
and the second after that,
and the offense for encouraging a woman to have sex,
and the offense for keeping an extra robe.
Hair, the offense for washing feet,🔽and the offense for making a hut,
and the offense for stealing, and the offense for teaching,
and the thirteen without permission.
These thirteen origins
are thought of by the wise;
In each origin
similar things are seen here.”
The first origin of offenses entailing expulsion
Sexual intercourse, touching,
the first is undetermined;
Previously, afterwards, and cooked,
in private with a nun.
In public, in private, and two,
a finger, in water, and laughing;
Striking, and also lifting,
and the fifty-three rules to be trained in.
Anusvāra, and going to a village, and drunk,
And the palm-leaf fan, and the purification;
The rains residence, and the exhortation,
And the not following, and the wandering.
These are the seventy-six training rules,
Which are done by body and by mind;
All have the same origin,
